headline: Ford CEO: US trade deal with Mexico, Canada 'critical for our country'
summary: Ford (F) plans to pivot on its EV strategy in 2026 to better compete with Chinese automakers, including a more focused approach to hybrid vehicles as the US company cancels its F-150 Lightning electric pickup line. Ford CEO Jim Farley sits down Yahoo Finance Senior Autos Reporter Pras Subramanian from the 2026 Detroit Autos Show to address a variety of topics, including the "critical" points of the United States–Mexico–Canada Agreement (USMCA), the Big Three automaker's refreshed perspective on electrification trends and EV demand, the new vehicles announced at the event, and the company's partnership with Formula One racing teams. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Catalysts.

content.title: Ford CEO: US trade deal with Mexico, Canada 'critical for our country'
content.description:
Ford (F) plans to pivot on its EV strategy in 2026 to better compete with Chinese automakers, including a more focused approach to hybrid vehicles as the US company cancels its F-150 Lightning electric pickup line.

Ford CEO Jim Farley sits down Yahoo Finance Senior Autos Reporter Pras Subramanian from the 2026 Detroit Autos Show to address a variety of topics, including the "critical" points of the United States–Mexico–Canada Agreement (USMCA), the Big Three automaker's refreshed perspective on electrification trends and EV demand, the new vehicles announced at the event, and the company's partnership with Formula One racing teams.

headline: White House Always Answers the Phone, Ford CEO Says
summary: Ford Motor Co. Chief Executive Officer Jim Farley says the Trump administration will "always answer the phone" and has been great to work with, but he says there is still a long list of issues to work through. He speaks to Bloomberg's Matt Miller.

content.title: White House Always Answers the Phone, Ford CEO Says
content.description: Ford Motor Co. Chief Executive Officer Jim Farley says the Trump administration will "always answer the phone" and has been great to work with, but he says there is still a long list of issues to work through. He speaks to Bloomberg's Matt Miller.
